awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraints on the Lithospheric Structure and Accretionary History of New England: Integrating Seismic and Geologic data sets
awd_abstract_narration:
The Wilson tectonic cycle is one of the most fundamental processes leading to growth and modification of continental crust on Earth. It involves the closing of ocean basins, collision of continents, rifting (separation) of continents, and formation of new ocean basins. Eastern North America provides a complete record of the eastward growth of the continent during the closing of the ancestral Atlantic ocean, ?Iapetus?, and the opening of the modern Atlantic ocean. The region has been used as a type section and model of plate tectonics for decades. Although the surface boundaries between former continental fragments are increasingly well known, a persistent question involves the timing and processes involved with the growth and stabilization of the deep crust and mantle parts of the continent. The overall goal of this project, and a long-term theme of the EarthScope project in general, is to integrate high-resolution geophysical and geological data in order to build a truly four-dimensional (space and time) model for the growth of continental crust in this classic region. The density and distribution of seismic stations are excellent, including the EarthScope Transportable Array and many long-running permanent seismic stations. New geological, geochemical, and geochronological data have led to revision of the tectonic history and a re-assessment of terrane boundaries and ancestry in the northern Appalachians. This proposal aims to understand the characteristics of continental lithosphere (the crust and mantle parts of the tectonic plates) in New York and New England, to identify the boundaries between distinct terranes both at the surface and especially at depth, and to address long-standing open questions about the tectonic history of the northern Appalachians. New models and hypotheses developed in this project will have wide implications for character of the North American continent, the nature of the deep crust and mantle, and our understanding of continental growth in general.

This project seeks to associate the interior structure of the lithosphere of Eastern North America with its tectonic history, and to draw broad inferences for the nature of continental assembly.  Specifically, this proposal will address the following scientific questions: (1) What is continental lithosphere? Can we identify distinct lithospheric blocks and intra-lithospheric boundaries? What are the origins of these structures? (2) What/where are the major terrane boundaries? To what extent can geological boundaries be extended to depth? When were the major terranes added to the North American continent?  To address these questions, the project will develop a comprehensive seismic model of the crust and the mantle lithosphere in eastern North America. An advanced wave propagation simulation and inversion will provide a powerful way to constrain the three-dimensional seismic features of the crust and the mantle lithosphere. Teleseismic receiver function analysis will be used to identify and delineate sharp velocity/density discontinuities. Laterally variable and depth-dependent anisotropy will be resolved with receiver functions and shear-wave splitting studies, and used to highlight patterns of lithospheric deformation. Compilation and synthesis of existing geological data sets, and collection of new surface rock samples will complement the seismic component. A systematic integration of geological, geochronological and geochemical data sets will inform a re-assessment of the regional tectonic framework.  The project will support the career development of an early-career female geoscientist and help the development of a new seismology group at UMass Amherst. Expansion of seismology research and teaching has outstanding potential to attract undergraduate and graduate students at the Five-College Geology Consortium. It will support training of undergraduate and graduate students at UMass and Rutgers. Findings from this project will be introduced to 8th-12th grade girls through the Girls Inc. Eureka! Program (a national organization), a strong STEM-based collaboration between Girls Inc. of Holyoke, MA and UMass. Surficial geologic compilations will be uploaded and made available to schools, colleges, and universities throughout New England for critiques, collaboration, and educational use.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey

por.por_cntn:
This research project aimed to construct a comprehensive description of physical properties in the outer rigid shell of the planet, the lithosphere, for the northeastern part of the North American continent. A detailed description of the internal architecture of the continent was the goal of the project, with an aim of relating this internal architecture to the history of tectonic events that shaped it. 

This project used records of ground motion from distant earthquakes to probe the interior of the Earth to depths of ~200 km. Data were acquired by the Transportable Array element of the Earthscope program as well as by numerous other continuously operating seismic observatories in a region centered on New England   and including adjacent regions of Quebec, New Brunswick, New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania.  The Appalachian Mountains of New England were the primary focus of the study, with the Adirondacks region and parts of the St. Laurence River valley also included. 

Methods used to study the Earth’s interior exploit observed time series of seismic waves radiated by distant earthquakes to derive properties of rocks these waves have traversed. Assembling such records from numerous locations over a region makes it possible to map the internal properties (density, speed of seismic waves) indicative of composition, temperature, water content and other attributes. To avoid imprinting differences in observed data onto the inferred interior structure of the Earth the process of data assembly and analysis has to be highly uniform. Studies comprising this project emphasized assembly of comparable data sets from different observatories in the region, and carrying out data analysis in uniform systematic manner. The project yielded two main results, each in a form of a detailed regional map of specific seismological properties of the region. 

The first study documented the presence of systematic texture within the rocks in the upper 200-300 km beneath the surface. Such texture forms in response to either past or ongoing deformation of rocks at depth. Mapping the texture of rocks is means to reconstructing past tectonic events and detection of ongoing processes such as tectonic plate motion. The main finding in this part of the project was that the deep-seated texture beneath northeastern North America is systematically regionalized.  Intriguingly, the outlines of these areas of systematic deep texture generally do not align with the outlines of the Appalachian Mountains in New England, but rather cut across the trends in them. This mismatch implies that deep parts of the lithosphere were shaped by processes not recorded by the surface rocks, an insight that will guide future studies of how Earth’s continents form and evolve. 

The second study mapped internal layering of the lithosphere, detecting abrupt vertical changes in seismic properties of rocks at depth. Numerous vertical boundaries in properties were found throughout the region. Their distribution is a good guide to the vertical extent of the rigid lithosphere, as preservation of such abrupt changes is possible within it, but is unlikely in the weaker region beneath it. One key outcome of this effort is a systematic variation of the maximum depth where layering is detected, roughly in agreement with the age of rocks on the surface. The billion years old Adirondack region is underlain by a lithosphere nearly 50 km thicker than the adjacent younger (300-400 million years old) Appalachian Mountains of New England. A surprising element of this result is a very short (tens of km) distance over which the change in the lithosphere thickness takes place. This short distance attests to the long-term strength of Earth’s tectonic plates. Another outcome of this study is a lack of an obvious correlation between the attributes of layering within the lithosphere and the regions of systematic rock texture delineated by the first study. While not yielding a satisfyingly simple explanation, this mismatch is quite important as it motivates the need for further exploration of the landmasses on which humanity resides. 

Most of the research done within the project was conducted by a group of students at different levels of study. Rutgers MS student Yiran Li took the lead in both efforts, carrying the second one over into her PhD research program at Binghamton University. Two Rutgers undergraduates  (Stephen Elkington and Janine Hlavaty) assisted with the first study.  Rutgers PhD student Xiaoran Chen collaborated on the second one. Upon her defense of a PhD thesis, Dr. Chen further contributed to the project during her postdoctoral training, performing similar studies in adjacent region in Quebec where rocks on the surface are 2.7 billion years old or more, and to a similarly old region in Australia. These much older regions appear to be systematically different from New England, an outcome consistent with a notion that processes acting on Earth prior to ~2.5 billion years ago were different due to the progressive cooling of the planet over time. 


Last Modified: 12/31/2022
Modified by: Vadim Levin
